reviewText: I've never had the opportunity to see R.E.M. live, and since they are now retired unfortunately never will. This concert DVD really makes me wish I had seen them live, R.E.M. puts on a fantastic concert and have just so much energy!!! Great audio quality also!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm getting caught up with my REM history because for some reason that I can't quite figure out, I drifted away from them.  Anyway, this concert is like being there.  WOW. They look great, sound excellent and the selection of songs is marvelous.  I have to agree with one previous reviewer and say that Peter Buck stole this show.Another high point of this DVD is Bill Berry on drums and of course, Mike Mills, my favorite REMer, in his sparkly Nudie Suits with his distinctive voice.My only complaint is that I wish they had fit at least *one* song into the set list where Mike sang lead.REM will always be my favorite group, they don't fit into any musical category as far as I'm concerned and there will never be another REM.Along with Tour Film and my 1985 Rockpalast DVD I will play this show over and over and over again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The "Monster" album remains controversial for many REM fans but in my book it remains my favorite album of REM. This DVD captures REM at the end of the "Monster" tour, and the band is in peak form.The "Road Movie" DVD (94 min.) is a faithful transfer of the original VHS movie, without any extras or bonus features, but with a noticably better sound quality. The song selection features most of the "Monster" albums tracks (8 of the 20 songs), and then some additional similar-sounding songs that would eventually end up on REM's next album ("Untertow", "Binky the Doormat" and "Wake-Up Bomb"). The sound is of course electric guitar-heavy and distorted, and if that is not your favorite REM sound, this DVD is not for you, although there are several more "traditional" REM songs such as "Losing My Religion", "Everybody Hurts" and "Man on the Moon". Peter Buck, not Michael Stipe, is the star of this movie (and it's hard to outshine Stipe), just watch him for example on "Star 69" and "Let Me In", wow.In all, a great concert movie, with outstanding audio quality, and with REM at its peak. But that's just my opinion.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is taken from a 3 night stand in Atlanta at the end of the Monster tour in '95.  It features a good cross section of R.E.M.s songs.  The video has a 'live' feel to it.  It's not an overblown production like the Rolling  Stones concerts have become (and I'm a big Stones fan).  The DVD features  sharp images and good sound plus you can skip directly to your favorite  songs without having to fast forward thru a tape.The only faults I  find with it is that it's strictly a song-by-song affair with no shots of  any type of interaction with the audience (between song banter etc.) and  emphasizes a few too many 'singing head' shots.  The band seemed to be a  little tired after a trying tour (at least on the night I saw them) and it  shows at times, but overall it's a good performance.
summary: Top notch concert video and good performance by the band.
Title: N/A
